summary: This is a Palm Beach Police Department case report from the OCVAN unit, documenting an initial investigation into Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein for potential prostitution activities. The report details intelligence from 2001 about Maxwell recruiting female students from Palm Beach Atlantic College, allegations of inappropriate touching by Epstein, and subsequent investigative steps including trash pulls and subpoenas for phone records. A later entry from 2008 notes Epstein's plea deal developments. This document is a compilation of police supplements detailing the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein from 2004-2020. It includes intelligence reports, surveillance logs, trash pulls, details of Epstein's 2008 plea deal and sentencing, his 2009 release, and a 2020 email referencing Bill Clinton. The supplements reveal ongoing police efforts to gather evidence of sexual activity with minors at Epstein's Palm Beach residence.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Described as an English woman who approached female college students on the Palm Beach Atlantic Campus, hiring them to answer phones at her home for $200 per day. She is associated with Jeffrey Epstein and the residence at 358 El Brillo Way.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Resident of 358 El Brillo Way, Palm Beach. Associated with Ghislaine Maxwell. Allegedly touched female students inappropriately. Owns multiple properties, vehicles, watercraft, and is associated with several corporations. Had a Florida concealed weapon permit.

persons.name: Sgt.
persons.context: Received and passed on initial intelligence about Maxwell and Epstein. Later participated in interviews with potential witnesses.

persons.name: Det.
persons.context: Primary investigator on the case. Conducted checks on Epstein and Maxwell, initiated trash pulls, served subpoenas for phone records, and coordinated with PBAC security.

persons.name: FBI agent
persons.context: Notified of findings regarding Epstein's plea deal developments in 2008.

persons.name: Jack A. Goldberger
persons.context: Epstein's attorney present at his 2008 plea hearing and who commented to media upon Epstein's release from jail in 2009.

persons.name: Guy Lewis
persons.context: Epstein's Miami attorney present at his 2008 plea hearing and representing him in civil cases.

persons.name: Howard J. Rubenstein
persons.context: Epstein's spokesman who issued a statement after the 2008 guilty plea, saying Epstein accepted responsibility.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Attorney representing underage girls who were victims of Epstein. He argued in federal court in July 2008 that the plea agreement was too lenient and contacted police about his clients.

persons.name: Deborah Dale Pucillo
persons.context: Palm Beach Circuit Court judge who sentenced Epstein in June 2008.

persons.name: Kenneth Marra
persons.context: U.S. District Judge who presided over a July 2008 hearing where attorney Brad Edwards challenged Epstein's plea agreement.

persons.name: Stephen Pentek
persons.context: Owner of a small red vehicle observed entering Epstein's property in August 2004.

persons.name: Igor
persons.context: Epstein's bodyguard/trainer observed walking with him in Palm Beach in August 2009 and present during an October 2009 deposition incident.

persons.name: Jessie
persons.context: Palm Beach sanitation employee who regularly collected and turned over Epstein's trash to detectives during the investigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey
persons.context: Palm Beach sanitation employee who collected trash from Epstein's property on March 31, 2005, and November 14, 2005.

connections.description: Live together at 358 El Brillo Way. Maxwell recruits young women for activities at their shared residence where Epstein is alleged to have acted inappropriately. They share phone accounts and financial associations.
Maxwell hires female students from Palm Beach Atlantic College to answer phones at her home, paying $200 per day in cash.
At least two female students complained about Epstein touching them inappropriately. One student reported Epstein made her uncomfortable by asking her to take her top off for a massage.
Maxwell is explicitly listed as an 'associate' of Epstein in the document. Her name was found on notepaper in his trash.
Goldberger was Epstein's defense attorney, present at his plea hearing and speaking to media on his behalf upon release.
Lewis was Epstein's Miami attorney, present at his plea hearing and representing him in civil lawsuits.
Igor is identified as Epstein's bodyguard/trainer, accompanying him during walks and to a deposition.
Edwards, as attorney for alleged victims, legally opposed Epstein, challenging his plea deal and filing civil suits.

events.title: Initial Intelligence Received
events.description: OCVAN unit receives intelligence from West Palm Beach PD concerning Ghislaine Maxwell hiring young women from PBAC to answer phones at her house for $200/day.

events.title: Trash Pulls Conducted
events.description: Police conduct intermittent trash pulls at 358 El Brillo Way, discovering items including nude photographs of women, lists of female names with ages/descriptions, massage directories, phone messages, and financial information.

events.title: Phone Record Subpoenas
events.description: Investigative subpoenas are served on Bell South for all incoming/outgoing calls from multiple phone lines at 358 El Brillo Way. Records are received and evaluated.

events.title: Witness Interviews
events.description: Sgt. and Det. interview female students who had worked at the residence. They confirm being paid well and feeling something was 'weird,' but did not observe anything illegal at the time.

events.title: Detailed Witness Account
events.description: Sgt. and Det. meet with a female student who reports nude photographs of women in the residence, topless women by the pool, frequent massages, and that Epstein made her uncomfortable by asking her to remove her top for a massage.

events.title: Plea Deal News Article
events.description: A Palm Beach Daily News article reveals Epstein's plea hearing was postponed. He had agreed to plead in state court to an 18-month imprisonment followed by house arrest and lifetime sex offender registration, but at the last minute wished to negotiate the registration requirement.

events.title: Epstein Pleads Guilty and is Sentenced
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty in Palm Beach Circuit Court to solicitation of prostitution and procurement of a minor for prostitution. He was sentenced to 18 months in Palm Beach County Jail, followed by 12 months of house arrest, and lifetime sex offender registration.

events.title: Victims Challenge Plea Agreement in Federal Court
events.description: Attorney Brad Edwards argued in U.S. District Court that the plea agreement was too lenient, worked out without victim consultation, and prevented federal prosecution for abusing other victims.

events.title: Epstein Released from Jail
events.description: Epstein was released from Palm Beach County Jail just before dawn after serving less than 13 months of his 18-month sentence. He was placed on probation and house arrest at his El Brillo Way home.

events.title: Epstein Allegedly Violates No-Contact Order
events.description: Epstein and his bodyguard Igor allegedly showed up unannounced to a victim's deposition, stared at and smirked at the victim, causing her to burst into tears and leave. The ASA sought prosecution for violating the no-contact order.

events.title: News Reports of Epstein's Death
events.description: News outlets reported the death of Jeffrey Epstein, who was found unresponsive in his cell at the Manhattan Correctional Center while awaiting trial on federal sex trafficking charges. His death was investigated as an apparent suicide.

events.title: Commencement of Trash Pulls and Surveillance
events.description: Detectives began conducting surveillance and trash pulls at Epstein's 358 El Brillo Way residence as part of the sexual battery investigation. This led to the collection of mail, notes with names/numbers, and a purple object believed to be a sex toy.

locations: 358 El Brillo Way, Palm Beach, FL 33480
358 El Brillo Way, Palm Beach, Florida
Manhattan Correctional Center, New York, NY
keyFacts: Initial intelligence from December 2001 indicated Ghislaine Maxwell was recruiting young female students from Palm Beach Atlantic College to answer phones at her home for $200 per day in cash, and at least two students complained about Jeffrey Epstein touching them inappropriately.

Trash pulls at 358 El Brillo Way in early 2002 revealed nude photographs of women, lists of female names with ages and descriptions titled 'People that I want you to meet,' massage directories, and references to massages in daily calendars and phone messages.

One female student interviewed in April 2002 reported that the residence had nude photographs of women, topless women by the pool, people always getting massages, and that Epstein had made her uncomfortable by asking her to take her top off for a massage.

Despite the suspicious activities and allegations, the police report concludes that 'no illegal activity has been reported or detected' at the time, and the information is to be kept for intelligence purposes only.

A 2008 update notes a news article revealing Jeffrey Epstein's plea deal negotiations, including an 18-month imprisonment, house arrest, and lifetime sex offender registration, which he attempted to renegotiate at the last minute.

Police conducted extensive surveillance and trash pulls at Epstein's Palm Beach home from March 2005 onward, collecting items including notes with girls' names and phone numbers, and pieces of what appeared to be sexual toys.

Epstein's 2008 plea agreement resulted in an 18-month jail sentence and lifetime sex offender registration, but it was criticized by victims' attorneys for being too lenient and for preventing federal prosecution for crimes against other victims.
An intelligence report from March 2004 details a woman (name redacted) who reported that Epstein had asked her several times to take off her top or pants, which she refused.

Epstein was released from jail in July 2009 after serving less than 13 months and was placed under house arrest. In October 2009, he allegedly violated a no-contact order by intimidating a victim at her deposition.

A September 2020 external email forwarded to police references 'Epstein's Buddy Clinton,' accusing former President Bill Clinton of being a 'Guest Of Honour' at Epstein's parties and making inflammatory claims about his conduct.
